sen.j: 雄琴神社（おごとじんじゃ）は、滋賀県大津市雄琴温泉にある神社である。
sen.e: Ogoto-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Ogoto Hot Springs, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.
Ogoto-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Ogoto-onsen Hot Springs, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.
sen.cmt: Ogoto Hot Springs > Ogoto-onsen Hot Springs
sen.e: Ogoto-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Ogoto-onsen Hot Springs, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.
Enshrined deities
Enshrined Deities
Enshrined Deities

sen.j: 当地を治めていた小槻氏の祖である今雄宿禰（いまおのすくね）を主祭神とする。
sen.e: The main deity is Imaonosukune, the ancestor of the Ozuki clan, which governed the region.
The main deity is IMAO no Sukune, the ancestor of the Ozuki clan, which governed the region.
The main deity is IMAO no Sukune, the ancestor of the Ozuki clan, which governed the region.

sen.j: 今雄宿禰は垂仁天皇の皇子・意知別命の後裔と伝えられ、仁寿元年（851年）に雄琴荘を拝領し、元慶8年（884年）に歿した。
sen.e: It is said that Imaonosukune was a descendent of Ochiwake no mikoto, the prince of Emperor Suinin, and he was bestowed Ogoto manor in 851 and died in 884.
It is said that IMAO no Sukune was a descendent of Ochiwake no mikoto, the prince of Emperor Suinin, and he was bestowed Ogoto manor in 851 and died in 884.
It is said that IMAO no Sukune was a descendent of Ochiwake no mikoto, the prince of Emperor Suinin, and he was bestowed Ogoto manor in 851 and died in 884.

sen.j: ほか、早良親王・大国主などを配祀する。
sen.e: Also, Prince Sawara and Okuninushi are enshrined as associated deities.
Also, Prince Sawara and Okuninushi are enshrined as associated deities.
Also, Prince Sawara and Okuninushi are enshrined as associated deities.
History
History
History

sen.j: 社伝によれば、大同_(日本)3年（808年）、雄琴山上に鎮座したという。
sen.e: The shrine tradition says it was first located on top of Mt. Ogoto in 808.
The shrine tradition says it was first located on top of Mt. Ogoto in 808.
The shrine tradition says it was first located on top of Mt. Ogoto in 808.

sen.j: ただし、これは今雄宿禰が歿するかなり以前であるので、当社に今雄宿禰が祀られたのはその歿後とみられる。
sen.e: However, as that was a long time ago before Imaonosukune died, it is believed that Imaonosukune was enshrined after he died.
However, as that was a long time ago before IMAO no Sukune died, it is believed that IMAO no Sukune was enshrined after he died.
However, as that was a long time ago before IMAO no Sukune died, it is believed that IMAO no Sukune was enshrined after he died.

sen.j: 今雄宿禰が当地を拝領してからは、同市苗鹿にある式内社・那波加神社とともに氏神として崇敬した。
sen.e: After Imaonosukune was bestowed the manor, he revered the shrine as ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) along with a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki law), Nahaka-jinja Shrine located in Noka in the same city.
sen.cmt: 今雄宿禰が雄琴山上に建てられていた神社を崇敬した、という意味に解釈しました。
sen.e: After IMAO no Sukune was bestowed the manor, he revered the shrine as ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) along with a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki law), Nahaka-jinja Shrine located in Noka in the same city.

After IMAO no Sukune was bestowed the manor, he revered the shrine as ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) along with a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki law), Nahaka-jinja Shrine located in Noka in the same city.

sen.j: 寛正3年（1462年）、今雄宿禰の末裔の壬生彦五郎胤業が下野国壬生に赴任し、当社から今雄宿禰の神霊を勧請してその地にあった藤森神社に合祀し、雄琴神社 (壬生町)に改称した。
sen.e: In 1462, a descendant of Imaonosukune, Hikogoro Tanenari Mibu, was appointed to Mibu, Shimotsuke Province, and calling on the divine spirit of Imaonosukune from the shrine, enshrined it together in the local Fujinomori-jinja Shrine, and changed its name to Ogoto-jinja Shrine.

In 1462, a descendant of Imaonosukune, Hikogoro Tanenari MIBU, was appointed to Mibu, Shimotsuke Province, and calling on the divine spirit of IMAO no Sukune from the shrine, enshrined it together in the local Fujinomori-jinja Shrine, and changed its name to Ogoto-jinja Shrine (Mibu-machi).
sen.cmt: Hikogoro Tanenari Mibu > Hikogoro Tanenari MIBUImaonosukune > IMAO no Sukune(Mibu-machi)を追記しました。
sen.e: In 1462, a descendant of Imaonosukune, Hikogoro Tanenari MIBU, was appointed to Mibu, Shimotsuke Province, and calling on the divine spirit of IMAO no Sukune from the shrine, enshrined it together in the local Fujinomori-jinja Shrine, and changed its name to Ogoto-jinja Shrine (Mibu-machi).
